[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/blob/master/neutron_tempest_plugin/api/base.py#L259

In fact this method was used to "Create QoS BW Limit" only and all his "friends" like: List, Update, Delete and Show has been implemented in another file: "network_client.py" (L630 -:L680):
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/+/806977/9/neutron_tempest_plugin/services/network/json/network_client.py#b630

Now, after this Tempest commit: https://github.com/openstack/tempest/commit/ca3e51356502b6bca86fa5b2c81f2805aecb06f0 we have all "QoS Limit BW" APIs in one place (which is Tempest and the best choice for stuff like that I think), so there is no more need to have methods doing the same stuff in Neutron Tempest Plugin, that was the reason for removing all of them.

Usually "QoS BW Limit Rule" tests are using not only "Create", it comes with : List, Show (Delete in cleanup) e.t.c. so once you have "QoS client" created in "setup_clients" you can simply use wherever you need directly from Tempest code.

What happens in the case where you have an admin_or_owner rule? Let's say I'm the owner of the resource I am operating on, but I don't have the admin role. What happens at the RBAC check? Based on the description of Scoped RBAC, I would assume the RBAC check to fail because I don't have the 'admin' role. But, I *am* the resource owner, which is a now separate check done at a different time by a different piece of software. Technically, if I am the owner of the resource I should be allowed to access it, but if the RBAC check fails before the "ownership" is checked, does the whole request fail?

As a deployer, how do I go about building policy rules that consist of both types of checks? Am I still required to update policy.json files and the keystone API?

Exactly - for cases where we want to enforce owner == user.id we are required to make the RBAC check pass in order to enforce the ABAC check. This makes for terrible user-experience if a specific role is removed from a user that happens to be the owner of something. The ABAC check breaks because we did something unrelated to the policy for it.

admin_or_owner will still pass.  3 cases ( I think)

A. admin role on admin project
B. admin role on resource's project 
C. member role on resource's project

Admin -> Member means that any of these roles will pass the RBAC check in middleware.

A. policy will enforce on is_admin/admin project as the override, and that will pass

B & C. policy will enforce that the role is a supported role, and the project matches

For the keystone cases where "owner" means that the user id needs to match, the policy check that currently is in force will still be in force.  That check will still be done in oslo-policy, not RBAC.
i'd prefer this go in it's own backend, no need to trample on resource
It belongs in resource.  Specifically, it belongs with the role backend.  There should be a referential intergrity constraint between an API and a  role, or we have breakage.

I not entirely sold on using the URL for the pattern. What if a service has an operation that is available across more than one API? That would require more than one api_role for each api + operation combination. From the perspective of the policy writer, I just want to make sure all list_server calls require the `reader` role. We're making the policy writer duplicate policy for every operation that happens to be supported across multiple APIs. What happens if they are inconsistent (user-experience will be terrible)? If they are ever out of sync, there would be inconsistent RBAC enforcement based on whatever version of the service API a user accessed. A user would be allowed to do an operation using one version of an API but not on another. If we default operations to requiring `Member` we could be exposing privileged operations to people who don't have the required role if the operator hasn't updated *all* versions of their api_roles in keystone. On the contrary, if we default to using `admin` for all non-specified operations then we make it impossible for users to do basic things if they just happen to be using a service API that was just released. What happens when a service rolls out a new version of an API? Are developers for that service going to have to script migrations to add api_roles to keystone that deployers are required to run before opening up a new API?

As a deployer, if I want change the policy for a specific operation, I'll have to make sure that I've updated *each* api_role for all API versions a service has as well as make changes to my policy.json files. Problems I have faced (and others based on the previous operator sessions, etc) are:
* what are changes in policy defaults for this release?
* what changes do I need to make to my existing overrides?
* are there new policy rules or new APIs I should worry about now?
* how can I check if I got the policy correct for a specific set of users?

Nova is moving towards fixing those by (I admin this runs the risk of incrementalism):
* Move defaults into the code, like with configuration
* Deployer only needs to specify over-rides, by default there doesn't have to be any policy file in place
* On upgrade its now clear what the deployer has changed previously, and by default all new policy rules just run with their defaults
* nova-policy CLI tool to help test if you have setup your policy rules correctly, by doing dry run checks

Now there is much more work to do on this particular journey:
* add more richness into the default policy (more clearly scoped users, read-only users, support users, non-destructive actions users)
* better support for hierarchical projects (largely a quota effort, but it helps stop many policy hacks done today)
* once we have hierarchical projects, we can hard code the scope in the code (project vs user, "admin/global_scope" override), and remove the current confusing no op default policy rules.
* better docs so its clear what the policy rules affect
* ability to rename / alias policy rules so we can meet our upgrade promises, similar to what is done with configuration
* evolve the existing rules into ones that more closely matches how deployers think about the API and its policy, without breaking existing policy modification folks
* add more hierarchy, so its easy to just disable resize or disable live-migration, you disable all the related API operations in one rule.

swift/container/backend.py.message: on un-recreated databases the oldest status_changed_at storage policy index wins
I can't find a usage that does not pass timestamp, so perhaps we should eliminate the optional default to simplify understanding of this method

This is a significant change but is not covered by any unit test (a probe test does fail if I revert this change)

I actually think this may be accidentally (but fortuitously) part of fixing a different existing bug with replication (independent of the topic of this patch)...

When the replicator calls this method [1], it passes 'now' as the timestamp. This method is only called if incorrect_policy_index is true (or the container has been recreated). I wonder if the replicator was forced to pass 'now' as the new status_changed_at just in order for the status_changed_at to be applied in this method, because this method was *broken*. With this change, the replicator calls could pass the status_changed_at time that came with the correct policy index, and that status_changed_at would now be applied. That would make more sense.

This is rooted in the fact that spi anomalously obeys an 'oldest trumps' rule, unless deleted. Looking at merge_timestamps, it is easy to see how newest wins could have been accidentally applied to status_changed_at.

So, existing replication of policy indexes may be broken:

consider a split brain new container with replicas R0, R1 and R2:

  R0 has spi=0, sca=t0 (sca == status_changed_at)
  R1, R2 have spi=1, sca=t1

this should resolve to all replicas having spi=0

  R0 syncs with R1 at t2:
    R0 has spi 0 at sca t0, R1 has spi 1 at sca t1
    -> R1 has incorrect policy index so R1 sets spi=0, sca=t2

  R1 syncs with R2 at t3:
    R1 has spi 0 at sca t2, R3 has spi 1 at sca t1
    R1 has incorrect policy index so R1 sets spi=1, sca=t3. <- BAD DECISION!

and so on... (obviously a test to prove/reproduce that would be great!)

If I am correct (replication spi sync is broken) then I'd advocate for this change moving to a parent patch that fixes replication, before we try to fix root-shard consistency.

[1] in container replicator _handle_sync_response() and _handle_sync_request()->_get_synced_replication_info():

I think this order of operatoins is robust to a crash between set-spi and merge-ts

If we wanted to add some metadata that includes the broker-id and the local info timestamps "just in case" I'd be totally fine with that - I expect draining and recreating sharded buckets to be uncommon; but when it does happen I'm most glad to know it will be *correct*

Also, the formatting you have specified will return lower case, so make it consistent. For example: 

except OSError:
    mac = "de:a0:b1:%02x:%02x:%02x" % (random.randint(0,255),
                                       random.randint(0,255),
                                       random.randint(0,255))

I think the logic in this assertion is coupled with the logic in create_namespaces. I think some more general purpose utilities/assertions would make the tests more readable. For example (using pseudocode but trying to communicate the general idea):

  def test_list_namespaces(self):
      public_ns = self.client.create_namespace(visibility='public')
      private_ns = self.client.create_namespace(visibility='private')
      public_ns_alt = self.alt_client.create_namespace(
          visibility='public')
      private_ns_alt = self.alt_client.create_namespace(
          visibility='private')

      resp = self.do_request('list_namespaces',
                              client=self.client)
      namespace_ids = [ns['id'] for ns in resp.json['namespaces']]
      self.assertIn(public_ns['id'], namespace_ids)
      self.assertIn(private_ns, namespace_ids)
      self.assertIn(public_ns_alt, namespace_ids)
      self.assertNotIn(private_ns_alt, namespace_ids)

The above requires me to understand the common utilities like create_namespace and do_request, but those are relatively straight forward methods. As opposed to having to understand the internals of create_namespaces, the format of what it returns, and how that should be used with the assertion we're introducing.

Even though it looks straightforward and easy to understand, if we decide to follow this structure then I need to follow it in every test of all metadef modules, like for objects, resource_types, properties and tags I need to create public and private namespaces for each project in each test first.

So I think it is better to have one method in utility class which will create these namespaces for me and call that method in each test.
I think these two loops are effectively testing the same persona (project-admin). They can both view all namespaces because they're technically considered system-administrators.

'CentOS-Stream-AppStream.repo' is the system default one (for centos stream), and 'enable-compose-repos' will create another repo file with compose info (CentOS-Stream-8-20210907.n.0-AppStream.repo). So we are disabling the conflicting 'appstream' repo here.

utilities/platform-util/scripts/show-cer.message: I don't think this works if multiple WAD certs are configured. You are checking the secretName under extraVolumes and the rootCA under the connectors config in the overrides. Consider a configuration with multiple connectors, each requiring a different rootCA. Your current code would only display one of the rootCA certificates.

Please take a look at my solution.

It works, but it is based on the assumption that the secret for WAD has only one file (key inside secret). This assumption is true based on docs like https://docs.starlingx.io/security/kubernetes/configure-oidc-auth-applications.html that has 'kubectl create secret generic wadcert --from-file=ssl/AD_CA.cer -n kube-system' as instructions for creating the WAD secret.

It could get fancier, but for that I would need to parse yaml to make sense of the values in it. I'm afraid I might have to use external libs or python for that.

can we rename this? "WAD_CA_CERT_KEY" makes it sound like the root CA key, which is not what the file is. The file is the certificate while "WAD_CA_CERT" is the secret name. Also just for reference, there are actually no defaults. The code seems to work when given a secret that does not exist though.
I meant key in the sense that a secret is a key-value store. I understand that it is confusing in the context for certificates and certificates keys though. Thanks for pointing it out.
Can $WAD_CA_CERTS be empty here? It would be an error condition causing the script to fail. Same for $WAD_CA_CERT_FILES in the line below.
Oh, yes, that's correct. Sorry, I thought that would be an error condition but it's not.

Yes, they can be empty here, but the for loop works fine even if empty. It will just not enter the loop. 
Good point though.
